Graphical abstract A series of Pd/FeO x catalysts were prepared using co-precipitation method via controlling the washing operation after co-precipitation of the catalyst precursors. The prepared catalysts were tested by the hydrogenation reactions of nitrobenzene, benzaldehyde and styrene, respectively. The highest activity could be obtained when the catalyst precursors were washed for ten times containing ∼2.2ppm chlorine concentration in the aqueous phase. XPS characterization suggested that a suitable Pd0/Pd δ+ ratio might be important for the high activity. TEM characterization showed that smaller nano-Pd particles can be generated and TPR characterization suggested the formation of more easily reducible Pd species when the catalyst precursors were washed for 10 times. Less or over-washing of the catalyst precursors result in coagulation of the nano-Pd particles. The washing operation, chlorine concentration, catalyst structure and catalytic performance can be related reasonably. The current results should promote the controllable preparation of active Pd-based catalysts. Keywords Nano-Pd catalyst Heterogeneous catalyst Controllable preparation Hydrogenation 1 Introduction It is well accepted that the presence of chlorine in noble metal catalysts normally results in aggregation of nanoparticles, and the chlorine might be adsorbed on the active sites of the catalyst, which often causes deactivation of the catalyst. Therefore, it is well adopted that the removal of chlorine from the catalyst is essential to gain active catalysts [1–9]. However, there is no direct evidence to prove that the low activity is caused by the presence of chlorine. It cannot be concluded definitely that it is the essential step to obtain active catalysts by removing the chlorine completely. Recently, much effort was focused on this field and the role of chlorine in active catalyst fabrication was explored. For example, the presence of chlorine had little impact on the activity of the unwashed and un-calcined supported nano-Au catalysts [10]. During the preparation of nano-Au-based catalysts, active Au/FeO x catalysts for CO oxidation could be prepared by co-precipitation method even the chlorine was maintained in the catalyst precursor if the catalyst was dried at low temperature. Moreover, the presence of chlorine could be an effective promoter to enhance the performance of catalysts for some reactions [11–15]. For example, in the styrene epoxidation reaction on Au (111), the introduction of chlorine significantly improved the selectivity of styrene oxide by inhibiting over-oxidation, and the rate of styrene oxide formation was increased, too [16]. Also, the addition of chlorine could optimize the redox characteristic of surface molybdenum oxide species, i.e. depression of the reduction potential of Mo6+, which leads to increased selectivity of ethylene on Mo/Si:Ti catalysts in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane [17]. In the last years, the controllable preparation of active supported nano-Au or Pd catalysts was explored in our group by controlling an optimum chlorine concentration in the aqueous solutions containing the catalyst precursors. During the preparation of Au/Fe2O3 catalyst with co-precipitation method, we have found that the activity of Au/Fe2O3 for CO oxidation and for reductive N-alkylation of nitrobenzene were varied with the chlorine concentration in the aqueous solutions containing the catalyst precursors, and the catalytic activity of Au/Fe2O3 reached the maximum at an appropriate chlorine concentration, i.e. 1–3ppm [18]. We also prepared a series of Au/NiO x catalysts with co-precipitation method by tracing the chlorine concentration in the washing step and tested by the total oxidation of CO. The results indicated that Au/NiO x catalysts prepared from aqueous solutions with 4–8ppm chlorine can be active catalysts and the temperature for CO total oxidation was <0°C. The catalytic activity dropped sharply if the chlorine concentration was >8ppm or <4ppm [19]. The Pd/Fe(OH) x catalysts with different activities for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene can be controllably prepared by tracing the chlorine concentration in the aqueous solutions containing the catalyst precursors, and the catalytic activity dropped dramatically if the chlorine concentration was >18ppm or <8ppm [20]. Catalyst characterizations suggested that catalysts prepared from aqueous solutions containing different chlorine concentration possess different structure. Typically, much bigger nano-Au or Pd particles were formed if the catalyst precursors were over or less washed, in which the catalysts were prepared from solutions with lower or higher chlorine concentrations. In this work, a series of nano-Pd/FeO x catalysts were prepared with co-precipitation method by controlling the washing operations of the catalyst precursors. The variation of chlorine concentration during the washing operation was also studied. We chose the selective hydrogenation of nitrobenzene, benzaldehyde and styrene as model reactions to investigate whether the activity of Pd/FeO x can be tuned by the washing operation or the chlorine concentration of catalyst precursor solutions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Pd/Fe2O3 catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method. Typically, 26mmol (10.5g) Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 1.5mL H2PdCl4 (2.8M) were dissolved in 4mL water and were drop-wise added into 150mL Na2CO3 solution (0.47M) in ∼0.5h under vigorous stirring. After it was further stirred for 1h, the reaction mixture was centrifuged and the recovered precipitates were re-dispersed into 300mL distilled water and were further ultrasonically washed for 1h. Then, the reaction mixture was separated into 6 pieces and all of them were ultrasonically washed again by deionized water respectively (50mL×4, 50mL×6, 50mL×8, 50mL×10, 50mL×12 and 50mL×14). All these samples were centrifuged and the resulting slurries were dried at 100°C for 6h, and were further calcined at 400°C in static air. The temperature was ramped from room temperature at a rate of 15°C/min to the final temperature and maintained for 5h. In the end, 6 pieces of dark-brown Pd/Fe2O3 catalyst samples (∼0.3g×6) were obtained and denoted as cat-1 to 6. The Pd/Fe3O4 catalysts were obtained by treating the cat-1 to 6 under hydrogen flow. The temperature was ramped from room temperature at a rate of 15°C/min to 200°C and maintained for 1h under hydrogen flow (20mL/min). In the end, 6 pieces of black Pd/Fe3O4 catalyst samples were obtained and denoted as cat-1-r to 6-r. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The TEM analysis was carried out on a FEI-TF20 field emission transmission electron microscope. The catalyst samples were dispersed in ethanol, and the solution was mixed ultrasonically at room temperature. A part of solution was dropped on the grid for the measurement of TEM images. XRD measurements are conducted by an X’Pert PRO (PANalytical) diffractometer. The XRD diffraction patterns were scanned in the 2θ range of 10–80°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was measured using a K-Alpha-surface analysis instrument with Al Kα radiation (1361eV). Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 77K using Micromeritics 2010 instrument. The pore-size distribution was calculated by Barrett, Joyner and Halenda (BJH) method from desorption isotherm. The Pd content of the catalysts was measured by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), using an Iris advantage Thermo Jarrel Ash device. The Cl− ion concentration in the aqueous phase containing the catalyst precursors was tested at 25.0°C through potentiostatic scanning on a CHI660D electrochemical workstation. A Cl− ion electrode was used as a working electrode and a platinum wire and an Ag/AgCl electrode were used as counter and reference electrodes, respectively. Before analysis, a series of Cl− ion standard solutions including 2.0ppm, 4.0ppm, 8.0ppm, 40.0ppm, 200.0ppm and 400.0ppm were prepared using NaCl as the Cl− ion source. The potentiostatic scanning was carried out at interval of 0.1s for 1min in the standard solutions, and the corresponding average potential value (mV) was obtained, which were repeated three times. The electrode system was calibrated with a 5.0ppm standard solution and the chlorine determination could be carried out through potentiostatic scanning when it is in the range of 5.0±0.5ppm. The test limit about this method is ∼1ppm. For the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurement, 13mg of catalyst balanced with 37mg SiO2 was placed in a quartz tube, and it was heated up to 350°C under 5mL/min O2 flow (10°C/min) and maintained 100min. The sample was then cooled down to 25°C under 50mL/min Ar flow and maintained for 1h at room temperature. Then the catalyst was heated up to 350°C under 20mL/min H2 (10%, balanced with N2) at a rate of 10°C/min. The amount of hydrogen uptake was monitored on-line by a TCD detector and recorded as a function of temperature. 2.3 Catalytic activity test Typically, 1.0mmol nitrobenzene, styrene or benzaldehyde, 10mg catalyst and 2mL EtOH were added into a glass tube (50mL), respectively. Then, it was exchanged with H2 and the reaction was carried out in the presence of H2 at atmospheric pressure (H2 balloon) at the given temperature. After reaction, 154mg biphenyl and 10mL EtOH were added for quantitative analysis by GC-FID (Agilent 7890A). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity study The influence of washing times on the catalytic performance of Pd/Fe2O3 for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene is examined first, and the results were shown in Fig. 1 . It could be seen that the conversion of nitrobenzene increased with the increasing of washing times until the washing times was up to 10, and then the conversion of nitrobenzene decreased with more washing times. Meanwhile, taking into account that other factor that might affect the catalytic performance, we examined the chlorine concentrations of the aqueous solutions from which the catalyst samples were prepared. It can be found that the catalytic activity of Pd/Fe2O3 in nitrobenzene hydrogenation can be related to the chlorine concentration reasonably. The catalyst had the best catalytic performance when the chlorine concentration in the aqueous solution was ∼2.2ppm. The conversion of nitrobenzene increased with the increasing of chlorine concentrations until that was up to ∼2.2ppm. When the chlorine concentration exceeded ∼2.2ppm, the catalytic activity of Pd/Fe2O3 decreased with the increasing of chlorine concentration. This observation was in agreement with our former results about nano-Au catalyst preparation for CO oxidation [18,19]. In order to verify the generality of the above rule, the catalytic activity of the Pd/Fe2O3 catalysts were further investigated in the hydrogenation of styrene and aldehyde and almost the same observations were got. Typically, in order to gain high activity, the supported palladium catalysts should be pre-treated by hydrogen especially when they were used in hydrogenation reactions. So the Pd/Fe2O3 catalysts were reduced under hydrogen flow to see if the hydrogen pre-treatment would influence the catalytic performance significantly. As it was discussed above, the obtained Pd/Fe3O4 catalysts were tested by the hydrogenation reactions of nitrobenzene, styrene and benzaldehyde and the results were given in Fig. 1. Clearly, the reduction of Pd/Fe2O3 results in more active Pd/Fe3O4 catalyst. Similar results were obtained even the reaction time was shortened to 1h, but the washing times give similar influence on the catalytic hydrogenation performance of the catalyst as on the un-reduced catalysts Pd/Fe2O3. The catalytic activity increased with the increasing of washing times when it was 4, 6, 8, or 10, respectively. However, the catalytic activity decreased with the increasing of washing times when it exceeds 10 times. About the relationship between chlorine concentration of the aqueous solution containing the catalyst precursors and the catalytic performance, it can be seen that similar rule as the un-reduced catalysts was observed, too. The catalytic activity increased with the increasing of chlorine concentration when the concentrations were 1.1, 1.5 and 2.2ppm, respectively, while the catalytic activity decreased with the increasing of chlorine concentration when the chlorine concentration of the aqueous phase containing catalyst precursors exceeded 2ppm. 3.2 Characterizations of Pd/Fe3O4 3.2.1 BET characterization Because similar rule between the washing times/chlorine concentration and catalytic performance was got with Pd/Fe2O3 and Pd/Fe3O4 catalysts, here only Pd/Fe3O4 was used as the model catalysts to check the catalyst structure variation when it was prepared from different conditions. In order to get comparable results, three typical catalysts including cat-1-r, cat-4-r and cat-6-r were extensively characterized by ICP-AES, BET, XRD, TEM, TPR and XPS. The basic physicochemical properties of Pd/Fe3O4 catalysts with different washing times during the preparation procedure are shown in Table 1 . It can be seen that Pd/Fe3O4 being washed 4 times has higher BET surface area than the catalyst being washed for 10 or 14 times, and the pore volume decreased with the increasing of washing times. The results of ICP-AES suggested similar palladium loadings in these three samples. Therefore the high catalytic activity should not be derived from the surface area and palladium loading variations. 3.2.2 XRD characterization Following, the catalysts were characterized by XRD and the XRD diffraction patterns are portrayed in Fig. 2 . Based on the XRD diffraction patterns, it can be seen clearly that almost all of the diffraction peaks can be attributed to the cubic phase of pure Fe3O4 phase, i.e. (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (333), (440), (620), (533) and (622), according to the JCPDS standard card [JCPDS Card No. 89-4319]. No characteristic diffraction peak ascribed to Pd species was observable, indicating that these palladium particles were well dispersed and no crystallized palladium formed [21]. 3.2.3 TEM and HR-TEM characterization The TEM and HR-TEM characterizations gave more information, according to the images of Pd/Fe3O4 catalysts with different washing times during the preparation procedure, Fig. 3 . Although similar TEM images were obtained, completely different micro-structures were observed based on the HR-TEM images. First, the average nano-Pd particle size in sample cat-1-r was 2.1nm, in which the catalyst precursors were washed for 4 times, Fig. 3(a) and (d). Interestingly, smaller nano-Pd particles formed when the catalyst precursors were washed for 10 times, in which it was only 1.1nm, Fig. 3(b) and (e). Surprisingly, bigger nano-Pd particles, i.e. 2.2nm, formed again if the catalyst precursors were further washed for another 4 times, Fig. 3(c) and (f). In addition, the nano-Pd particles were well dispersed on the surface of Fe3O4 in catalyst cat-4-r while coagulation occurred in catalysts cat-1-r and cat-6-r. Therefore the smaller nano-Pd particle and its well dispersion on the support might be one of the reasons for the high activity of catalyst cat-4-r. Finally, if we relate the nano-Pd particle size with the conversions of nitrobenzene, styrene and benzaldehyde in Fig. 1, it can be seen similar conversions of nitrobenzene, styrene and benzaldehyde were obtained when cat-1-r and cat-6-r were used as the catalysts, in which the average Pd particle sizes were 2.1 and 2.2nm. So the catalytic activity was well related to the particle size of Pd. 3.2.4 XPS characterization As the washing operation might influence the surface structure of the catalysts remarkably, the Pd/Fe3O4 catalysts were characterized by XPS. The results were shown in Table 2 and the Pd3d XPS spectra were shown in Fig. 4 . It can be seen that the peaks of Pd3d are consisted of more than one contribution. Thus, the Pd3d lines were de-convoluted to two peaks with the least-squares fitting routine using the Gauss functions. The Pd3d signals of the catalysts showed a maximum at 335.2eV, which agrees with the binding energy of metallic Pd. The small peak around 337.2eV is attributed to PdO x , and the binding energy is higher than the PdO, i.e. ∼336.0eV, which might be caused by the highly dispersion of nano-Pd particles on the support [22,23]. In addition, the ratio of Pd0 to Pd δ+ changed significantly in these catalyst samples, in which the only difference was that their precursors had been washed for different times. The ratio of Pd0 to Pd δ+ increased slowly with the increasing of washing times. The ratio of Pd0 to Pd δ+, i.e. 1.8:1, might be a suitable composition for high activity. Thus, the washing operation can be used as a factor for the controllable preparation of active nano-Pd catalysts for hydrogenation reactions. Catalyst with smaller nano-Pd size and suitable Pd0/Pd δ+ ratio can be prepared when the catalyst precursors were washed for suitable times. 3.2.5 TPR characterization From the results shown in Table 2, it can be seen that higher chlorine concentration seems to enhance the Pd reduction. It will be interesting to see its concentration effect on the TPR profiles of the catalyst samples, which might affect the properties of both Pd and FeO x , Fig. 5 . Clearly, from the TPR profiles of Pd/Fe2O3 it can be seen that more reducible Pd species formed in catalyst cat-4. The temperature for Pd reduction is at 86 and 101°C. However, the corresponding temperatures in samples cat-1 and cat-6 were 92 and 134°C. Similarly, the peak temperature for the reduction of FeO x in cat-4 was 258°C but it was 270 and 273°C in cat-1 and cat-6. Following, the catalysts cat-1, cat-4 and cat-6 were re-oxidized for the next run of TPR characterization. Clearly, completely different profiles were obtained. The reduction temperature of FeO x decreased to ∼129°C. Although the peaks for Pd species reduction were overlapped, it still can be seen that more reducible Pd species formed after reduction–oxidation cycle in cat-1-r, cat-4-r and cat-6-r, which should be responsible for their higher activity than cat-1, cat-4 and cat-6. Finally, although the reducibility of Pd species was different in cat-1, cat-4 and cat-6, more reducible Pd species were formed in Pd/Fe2O3 with more washing times because the Pd reduction peaks turned bigger synchronously. It is in good agreement with the observation of XPS, which suggested the formation of more Pd0 species with more washing times but more reducible Pd species were formed with suitable washing times. 3.3 Catalytic activity study 3.3.1 Catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene derivatives Next, the scope and limitations of catalyst Pd/Fe3O4 regarding to a range of structurally diverse nitro aromatics were examined. As the results shown in Table 3 , Pd/Fe3O4 exhibited high activity on the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene with full conversion (Table 3, entry 1). Then, the catalytic hydrogenations of nitrobenzene derivatives, which contain different electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups were tested. Clearly, the involving of methyl group at different positions affords the corresponding aniline in excellent yields, i.e. 97–99% (entries 2–4). The introduction of electron-donating groups influences the hydrogenation reaction less and good yields were also obtained. For example, >99% yields were obtained if m- or p-MeO-nitrobenzene was used as starting materials (entries 5–6). Also, the hydrogenations of m- and p-Cl-nitrobenzene were carried out. Disappointingly, hydrodechlorination reactions occurred although completely conversions were obtained. The yields of the aimed products were 70% and 73% (entries 7–8). Hydroxyl and amine groups were well tolerated for the hydrogenation of the nitro compounds to the corresponding amines catalyzed by Pd/Fe3O4, and the products were obtained almost quantitatively in 2h (entries 9–13). In the case of 1-nitro-naphthalene and 1,4-dinitrobenzene, Pd/Fe3O4 showed high catalytic activity on the hydrogenation reaction with >99% yields at 25–40°C in 2–3h (entries 14–15). The hydrogenation of 2,6-di-Me-nitrobenzene is difficult and it needs 3h to gain 94% yield (entry 16). The low activity of 2,6-di-Me-nitrobenzene might be caused by the steric hindrance of methyl groups. 3.3.2 Catalytic hydrogenation of olefins The catalytic hydrogenation of several olefins was further performed using cat-4-r, Table 4 . The hydrogenation of styrene can be finished in 20min with 98% yield to ethylbenzene (entry 1). The incorporation of methyl group retards the hydrogenation reaction slightly and 94% p-Me-ethylbenzene was obtained in 30min (entry 2). The α-Me-styrene can be hydrogenated efficiently and 99% yield to the desired product can be generated (entry 3). For aliphatic olefins such as cyclohexene and 1-dedecene they can also be hydrogenated and cylcohexane and dodecane can be synthesized with up to 99% yields (entries 4–5). So catalyst cat-4-r exhibits nice performance in the catalytic hydrogenation of olefins. 3.3.3 Catalytic hydrogenation of benzaldehyde derivatives Then the catalytic hydrogenation of benzaldehyde derivatives was carried out, Table 5 . For benzaldehyde, it can be quantitatively transformed into benzyl alcohol with >99% yield (entry 1). The presence of methyl, hydroxyl and methoxy functional groups influence the activity significantly but 95–99% yield were also obtained at 25–40°C in 12–16h (entries 2–4). 4 Conclusions In summary, the active Pd/Fe2O3 and Pd/Fe3O4 catalysts can be controllably prepared with co-precipitation method via controlling the washing operation after co-precipitation but before drying and calcination. Also, this procedure can be realized by tracing the chlorine concentrations in the aqueous phase during the washing of the precipitates. We found that the catalytic activity of Pd/Fe2O3 and Pd/Fe3O4 for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene, benzaldehyde and styrene reached the maximum at ∼2.2ppm chlorine when the catalyst precipitate was washed for 10 times, otherwise the catalytic activity would drop gradually. However, at this stage, it cannot be determined is the chlorine or the washing operation responsible for the catalytic activity variation. By applying the Pd/Fe3O4 catalyst, nitrobenzene, benzaldehyde and styrene with different substituted groups can be hydrogenated to the corresponding products with excellent yields under the optimized reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: A series of Pd/FeO x catalysts were prepared using co-precipitation method via controlling the washing operation after co-precipitation of the catalyst precursors. The prepared catalysts were tested by the hydrogenation reactions of nitrobenzene, benzaldehyde and styrene, respectively. The highest activity could be obtained when the catalyst precursors were washed for ten times containing ∼2.2ppm chlorine concentration in the aqueous phase. XPS characterization suggested that a suitable Pd0/Pd δ+ ratio might be important for the high activity. TEM characterization showed that smaller nano-Pd particles can be generated and TPR characterization suggested the formation of more easily reducible Pd species when the catalyst precursors were washed for 10 times. Less or over-washing of the catalyst precursors result in coagulation of the nano-Pd particles. The washing operation, chlorine concentration, catalyst structure and catalytic performance can be related reasonably. The current results should promote the controllable preparation of active Pd-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Active palladium catalyst preparation for hydrogenation reactions of nitrobenzene, olefin and aldehyde derivatives
